p: The receptacular nectaries of B. orientalis were supplied solely by phloem strands, and an inequality in phloem vascularization between lateral and median glands was observed, which is in accordance with the other Brassicaceae studied previously (see Frei 1955; Davis et al. 1986, 1998 and references herein). According to Frey-Wyssling ( 1955) and Fahn ( 1979b), there is a positive correlation between the amount of sugars in nectar and the amount of phloem elements supplying the nectaries. This correlation seems to be true for the species examined in this study, as the phloem elements are well developed in lateral glands. A remarkable feature of companion cells of phloem in B. orientalis nectaries is a lack of cell wall ingrowths. According to Davis et al. ( 1986), wall ingrowths were absent in companion cells of B. napus nectaries, but these cells may still function as transfer cells. They may play an important role in the unloading of phloem sap and passing pre-nectar constituents to secretory parenchyma cells and intercellular spaces next to them. The intercellular spaces are more or less conspicuous, but always are present among cells of this tissue.
